productText:
000
FXUS62 KTAE 201723
AFDTAE

Area Forecast Discussion
National Weather Service Tallahassee FL
123 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

...New AVIATION...

.UPDATE...
Issued at 1013 AM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Forecast is on track for this morning. No significant updates 
were made.

&&

.NEAR TERM...
(Today and tonight)
Issued at 321 AM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

For today, a drier airmass will allow for mostly sunny skies through 
the day for most of the area. The exception to this will be across 
the far southeast big bend where lingering moisture will allow for a 
slight chance of showers and thunderstorms to continue. Although 
high temperatures are still expected to be above average, the drier 
airmass will keep peak heat index values generally in the 95-100 
degree range for most of the area this afternoon. The exception will 
be along the immediate coast and across the southeast big bend where 
peak heat indices in the low 100s are still expected this afternoon.

For tonight, mostly clear skies with dry conditions are expected 
areawide with near average overnight low temperatures ranging from 
the upper 60s across the northwest to mid 70s across the southeast 
big bend.

&&

.SHORT TERM...
(Wednesday through Thursday night)
Issued at 321 AM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Upper trough over the Great Lakes will continue 
sliding off to the Northeast with a lingering shortwave in its wake 
over much of the US Southeast as a piece of vorticity may break off 
from the parent trough. An upper cutoff low may develop as a result 
in the short term, though guidance indicates that this may be 
delayed into the weekend. Regardless, this will serve to pump more 
moisture into the region increasing PoPs across our FL counties, 
particularly across the Big Bend. Daytime highs will be in the upper 
80s to low 90s with overnight lows in the upper 60s to low 70s. 

&&

.LONG TERM...
(Friday through Monday)
Issued at 321 AM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

The aforementioned upper cutoff low should form by 
Saturday, gradually retrogressing west toward the Southern Plains. 
PoPs should generally remain the same each day with elevated chances 
for rain across our FL counties with an emphasis toward the FL Big 
Bend, perhaps creeping up into our SW GA counties. With the slow 
movement of the upper low, our area will likely be stuck in this 
pattern throughout the majority of the long term forecast, if not 
entirely. Daytime highs will range from the low to mid 90s with 
overnight lows in the low to mid 70s. 

&&

.AVIATION...
(18Z TAFS)
Issued at 121 PM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

VFR conditions are expected over the next 24 hours. Some patchy
fog is possible near VLD around daybreak, but confidence is too
low to make any categorical changes. Winds will veer from out of
the NW this afternoon to out of the NE on Wednesday.

&&

.MARINE...
Issued at 1013 AM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

There may be a few showers/thunderstorms today in our eastern 
waters. As we head further into the week, winds will be variable, 
with easterly surges during the overnight hours beginning 
Wednesday night into the weekend. Seas will be 1 foot through 
midweek before increasing to 2-3 feet later this week into the 
weekend. Chances for showers and thunderstorms exist each day over
our waters, particularly in the morning and overnight hours, with
gusty and erratic winds near and within these storms.

&&

.FIRE WEATHER...
Issued at 321 AM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

The only fire concerns are high dispersions this afternoon west of 
the Apalachicola River extending from Southern AL down to the FL 
Panhandle I-10 corridor in the wake of a front fostered by 5kft-
7kft+ mixing heights. Rain chances then increase each successive day 
as moisture rebounds and winds turn more easterly.

&&

.HYDROLOGY...
Issued at 321 AM EDT Tue Aug 20 2024

Madison County Areal Flood Warning Update: Emergency 
Management continues to report gradually rising water levels in 
portions of southeastern Madison County east of Lee and areas around 
US 90 as well as areas south of I-10 east of State Road 53 and the 
Suwannee River. Water levels remain high in the vicinity of I-10 and 
exit 262, but flood waters are not impacting access to or travel on 
I-10. Flood waters are continuing to gradually shift slowly south 
and east toward the Suwannee River. 

The slow-responding Suwannee is in the process of a prolonged and 
flat crest in minor flood. The latest river forecasts call for a 
very slow fall through minor flood stage over the next 7 days.

Drier conditions will persist today, though a return to a wetter 
pattern appears likely in the extended with our FL counties 
appearing favored. Generally less than in inch is expected areawide 
through Monday. 

&&

.SPOTTER INFORMATION STATEMENT...

Spotter activation is not requested. However, spotters are always 
encouraged to safely report significant weather conditions when they 
occur by calling the office or tweeting us @NWSTallahassee.

&&

.PRELIMINARY POINT TEMPS/POPS...
Tallahassee   94  72  93  71 /   0   0  40  20 
Panama City   93  74  93  74 /   0   0  20  40 
Dothan        93  71  94  70 /   0   0  10  10 
Albany        94  71  93  71 /   0   0  20  10 
Valdosta      94  72  93  71 /   0   0  30  20 
Cross City    94  74  93  72 /  20   0  50  20 
Apalachicola  93  77  91  77 /   0   0  30  40 

&&

.TAE WATCHES/WARNINGS/ADVISORIES...
FL...High Rip Current Risk until 8 PM EDT /7 PM CDT/ this evening for 
     FLZ114.

GA...None.
AL...None.
GM...None.
&&

$$

NEAR TERM...DVD
SHORT TERM...Worster
LONG TERM....Worster
